Creating a new Jekyll Website

Jun 5, 2023

I decided to refresh my personal website so I built a new Jekyll website from scratch. Since GitHub Pages is powered by Jekyll, it is easy to deploy a site using GitHub. Another nice feature of Jekyll is that the documentation is through and easy to understand

To get my website up and running I followed the tutorials Installing Jekyll on macOS and Jekyll Quickstart.

The first step if you are on a Mac or Linux machine is to install Homebrew. Homebrew makes it easy to install and update packages. In a terminal run

/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"

Install chruby and ruby-install with Homebrew

brew install chruby ruby-install xz

Install the latest stable version of Ruby (supported by Jekyll):

ruby-install ruby 3.1.3

Configure your shell to automatically use chruby

echo "source $(brew --prefix)/opt/chruby/share/chruby/chruby.sh" >> ~/.zshrc
echo "source $(brew --prefix)/opt/chruby/share/chruby/auto.sh" >> ~/.zshrc
echo "chruby ruby-3.1.3" >> ~/.zshrc # run 'chruby' to see actual version

Now that ruby is installed you can install jekyll

gem install jekyll bundler

Create a new Jekyll site at ./myblog.

jekyll new myblog

Change into your new directory.

cd myblog

To view this locally

bundle exec jekyll serve

Your website should now be visible at http://localhost:4000
